India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: CAIRO AGRICUTLURAL SHOW
div.p: Tomorrow the biggest agricnltural show ever beld in Egypt will be inangorated at Cairo. The exhibition will be open from 8 p.m. ontil 6 p.m. to-morrow and from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on the lst, 2nd, 8rd, and 4th March. A military band will be in attendance.

A short preliminary description of the show may not be oat of place. The bnilding iteelf is fi led with an excellent collection of cottons of the various Moadiriehs, as well as grain. Vegetab'es are found in a separate kiorqne. The Society have many more animals than their shed really acoommod tes, and this year they have cattle, which they bave pot had for many years. Horses, moles. donkeys, camels, and sheep are found. A featare of the show is the representetion of native in- dustries, wocdwork, etc. Natives will be at work at their respective craf'e, and 800 me. tres of +beddi g will be occupied by these indastries. Technical echools are also exhi- biting. Machinery, ploughing tackle, as well as engines, pumpr, mills, etc, are *huwn.

div.head: LECTURE ON WAGNER
div.p: A very ifnt@erting lectare opon Wagner and his wogid'Was given on Monday afternoon by apts W.S Gairdner at Counanght Hone, siro, to a very appreciative andience. Mr. Gairdner devoted bis attention to Wagner as a mosician rather than a dramatist, showing very snccinctly the great diff -rence of bis works prodeced before 1830 and those of bis latter life, nrodoced after a lJapse of three or foor years, which period be devoyed to stody and to developing bis ideas. thon bh .w the-e earlier work, ‘) be F ying Datchman,” “Tann- hauser,” and ‘Lobevgrn,” were characterized by melodies pearly always metrical in char- acter, rbythmical in constraction, aod clearly governed by the words to which they were set; while his later works were of ar entirely d ff-rent character—free melodies with no soggestion of metre nor words, with bat little regolarity of form, illostrative of abstract thoughts or characters rather than words, aod almost invariably interpreted by the orchestra rather than the voice, which was mostly cor fined toa running recitative. Mr. Gairiper very clearly illustrated the metrical tendency of this early period, showing from exsmples taken fiom ‘'l'anubauser’ that the lyrics grouped them-elves almost jnvefiably into quatrain form, which arrangement was almost av obcession cf be day aid which often resvl'ed in mun>otopy if not in actual weekpes of compostion, ths masic being dominated by the words with more or less conventional cadanves. ‘l'bis form of lyric was the conventional one of the day; and M- Gairdner showed hw Hadyo, M zart, and otbers broke away from this stersotyped idea by their improvisation on the fragments of osrtain metrical themes. ‘T'his he exemplifi-d by the stream of free melody in Mossrt’s j ibilee symphony, and aleo by Beethoven's sym phony.in C. minor, of which the first foar chords boid ap nearly the whole movement Thongh there are certain traces of this use of free melody in some of Wagner's early works they were bat experimentnl;and it was nodoabt owing to bis years of stedy and realizstion of his tbeorie: that his later work are so char- rather than theory.

I: ig evident that Mr. Gairdners knowledze of the wot ject is extensive envagh to give bim materials for more lectnres thau the ore we li-teped to wih much pleasure oo Monday. Wagner’ mosi is au exbsostive su! jest ; and it Mr. G i dner can ouly be persaadei to give farther illusrations and explanations which will make it easier of comprehension ‘o the limited anderstanding bis remarks will be reeeived with becoming gratitude by many.

div.head: BRITISH RECREATION CLUB CAIRO
div.p: The first Bachelors’ Sapper held at the British Recreation Clob, Cairo, on Satarday evening last, was a credit alike to the promo- ters, the bachelore, and the caterers’ manager, and Mrs.Holmes. All the tickets were rapidly bought op, and the tastefully decorated sup- per hall and fi,wer bedecked tables, fally oceapied as they were by guests, presented a most pictare-que and animated spectacle. The menu (ali Bogli-h) was discussed ino very practical mauner after which a toast list end masical programme was submitted, aod carried throogh with rare spirit. The chair man, Mr. Aitcbesou—or as he is bet'er and more populary known at the clab as Artcheson ‘Bey”—gave of bis best, bis sparkling sallies fsirly convalsing the assemb'ed o mpany at times. His learned dissertation on Egyptology was a thing to be remembered, his apparent in timate knowledge of the history of the Tombs of the Sacred Balle somewhat stagger- ing his not too exsctjng atdidece He pro- posed the toast of ‘Phe Clab,” Mr. I-on that of the “Marriei Members,” to which latter Mr. Soow replied. Messrs. Walton, ‘Treasure, Watt, Haye:,Saew, Heywood, Ison, Stevenson, Kimmer, and Band Sergeant Geogebegan, contributed to the masical programme. Mr. Sammere, accompanying in his asaal accepta- ble manner, in addition to rendering sondry pisnuforte solos with taste and feeling. Votes of thanks t» the chairman ; to Mr. Sommers ; to the manager and Mrs. Holmes ; and to all who had onntribated to the success of the and ‘Gi S.ve the Kiog,” brooght a» bighy sucves+fal and harmonious evening toa close

div.head: MEETING TO-MORROW
div.p: The meating of the members of the General Assembly of the Legislative Conncil takes p'ace to-morrow. In virtne of the constitational law of the Egyptian Government, this Assembly meets every two years. The three last ocos sions on which it met were March 8, 19/2, F sbroary 22, 1904, and April 3, 1905 The lat‘or was an extraordinary meeting convoked bv Khedivial deoree as the Government had to acbmit to the General Assembly a decree relative to the measdres to be taken to figh: the cotten “Worm. Although this year the government lias no project of great importance tc communicate to the Arsembly, the meeting wil take place to-morrow in conformity with the organic decree. It will be held with the mcustomed ceremony at the Ministry of Piblic Works. The Khedive will open the sitting and deliver the customary speech

“The Gsneral Assembly is simply the Lagis lative Comncil over again, with the addition of the six ministers and of forty six members popularly elected. This Assembly bas no legis- lative fanetione, thoogh it is entitled to pass resolotions on any subject of public interest— resolations which 'he Government is tree to teke as moch or as little notice of as it pleaser. [t has, however, one most important power of a negative kind, inasmach as no new taxes e:n be imposed withont its consent. This is» provision which might evidertly some day or other enable the Assembly to play a vary onsiderable part in Egyptian pol ties. But, sitce 1888, the Government has been in the tortanate positioa of pot requiring to inipose pew taxes apon its native sabjeots, except the tax necessary to facilitate the alolitioa ot the corvée, which, for reasons already explained, the Assembly made no d fhi- ct lty aboat accepting. That bedy, therefore, his not been sammoned oftener than four pative qoestion in Africa seems liable to be| times since its oreation (the organic decree overlooked. ‘be possibility of large groaps of tribes, hitherto distinct and matoally antago- vistic, becoming rapidly able and esger to anderstand each other in some common form of speech, has apparently to be taken into account. Twenty-six years’ contact with Swahili and various dialects of Esstern and Central Africa points so far to the conclusion that there is a remarkable degree of sithilarity, amounting in many important respects to substantial ident- | ity, in the grammatical stractore of language over the whole vast area occupied by the races of Africa, from the Sudan to the Cape. _ The ffi iale, missionaries, traders, settlers and travelers of various nationalities who are qualified to give belp in testing this conclasion by personal and first-hand stady «fa Banta dialect are naterally difficalt to reach, scatter- ed in remote and cften isolated spheres of work. It is, therefore, perhaps justifiable to ask publicity for the request, that persons #0 qualified and willing to accept and reply to a brief commanication on the sabject would rend me their addresses at Fort Jameson, North Bastern Rhodesia. I should be grateful if foreign journals and local papers in Africa, general avd Official, would assist by calling p:oviding that it mast meet at least once every to years), and ite discassions bave generally been brief and colooriess. As far as can be jodged, ita characteristics do not differ mate- rislly from those of the Legislative Council, though as the proportion of Government nomineer, who form the best element of bo*b bodier, is emaller in the Assemb'y than in the Coancil, the decisions of the former won!d be more likely to prove fantastic and anworkable than those of the latter.”

div.head: THE SCHOOL OF CADIS
div.p: The regulations of the new Scho! of Cadis wire published yesterday afternoon, and the following note bas been commanicated to the P-eas by the Ministry of Public Instraction :— We give below the regula’ ions of the Cads’ Sshool, which have been drawa op by the Ministers of Poblic Lostroction and of Jastice, and approved after a minute examination by the Chancellor of Al Azhar U:iversity, the Grand Mafti, and several of the ulema. These regulations have been promulgated by Khe d vial decree under date of Febraary 25. They are established on the following bases, as shown in the note with reference to the same subject transmitted by the Minister of Education to the Council of Ministers

1. The stedentsa of the Sch ol of Cadis will receive from the moment they enter the school a thorough religious education and at the same time will be instrocted in the elements of aithmetioc, history, geography, caligraphy,etc., aid the legal knowledge necessary to enable them to falfil their fosikions in the Mehkemeh Coart.

2. On acconnt of the dependence of the a bool on the University of Al Ashar ard the opacity of the papils who have completed their ovurse to teach at the said university, the school will create a class of men “eapable of in spiring geveral confidence in their re'igious k :owledge and general ability.
3. The school will inclade two sections, the first of which will train very capable clerks and will serve as a preparatory school for the scond class.

div.head: FROM A PEDESTRIAN'S POINT OF VIEW
div.p: To rue Editor or tHe “Egyptian Gazettes’

Sir,—I shonld like to make some remarks iv voor colamas oa the above subject, which ems of interest both te visitors and to those whose welfare is involved in maintaining the oopalarity of this city as a place of resort. Dividing these remarks onder sanitation, traffic, and mendicity,

Firstly —Why is it considered necessary to varge the various templesdedicated to C nacina st 10 o'elock on a Sanday morning, which also appears to be the day and hoor fixed for shaking carpets, etc, ont of apper windows? Furthermore, coald not the aathorities orn cerned arrange to cleanse the varions street refase-bins béfere these receptacles become aa abomination?

Secondly as to trafic. The Sharia Gainena has been “ap” ever since Ootober, asphalte is beiog laid down, and this sf cted street has in rotation presented to the public a sketchy impression of the Bernese Alps, a fair coarse for an obstacle race, and an spirited representation of the destraction of the Cities of the Plain. This street is also a kind of cyclonic centre for dranken brawls, the gentle fe tah treqnents an Armenian liqnor den jast off the main strest, qnarrela in his caps over the favoars of one or more of the attendant Hebee, and goes out into the street t fight it oat with moch beilowing and thrashing of the air with sticks. After the whole neighbourhood has been aroused a shawish comes ap and appeals to the principal villaiti as a man ania brother to go home. This attifude is dae to inadeqrate available force and not t» fank, for I bave seen an Ezyptian policeman make 4 mst dptorained arrest of an intoxicated Bey whose friends stragg ed desperately to eff wt a rescue while the crowd all sympathised or covertly impeded the arrest. However, the policeman kept his temper and his man, and withoat drawing his tranchaon evantaally marched his bey--hip off to the oaracol.

Before leaving tha police, it might be askad why they do not, whon issaing licenses to arbaghie, insist on some test of driving and topography. Tha local Jeha has no ides of eithar, aod having also no “haols,” plies the whip savagsly and casselassly to cover his defects (printer p'esse note that thie is not a paradox). Accidente would be more treqaent if the horses were not anderfed | and the pace slow. He is however a sports- man in his way, and his chief recreation con- sists in endeavoaring to “ran down” wall- dressed Europeans. dast according to local atmos; heriowgndition®, or, if be bas a clear street before him and the khawagah does not look like a “sprinter,” he , can slash bim over the face with his whip. It is a safe amusement, too, for most Earopeans | koow better than take the case op. A month ago an arbaghi came op behind me along the Sharia Kamel and with the whole road to epare hagged the right side and withoot a word of , warniog | felt his off horse's shoulder cannon | into mine ; he had plenty"of space bat having some experience in “riding off” I got olear of his boofs and the wheels, bat still it was not a bad attempt. Io that same street shortly after, a friend of mine—an E iglishmin—had mach the same experience. He pat ap his hands instinctively to ward off the impact, and the driver slashed at him viciously with his whip as he passed. Stang and indig»ant, my friend gave chase to get the man’s uamber. The , vehicle tarned ap a side street and stopped. Finding no ommber on th@oarriags (it was after- | wards foand te belong to one of the hotels) ha | accosted the arbaghbi aod on the lat‘er refosing to give any account of himself proceeded to arrest him. There was a scofiis and the Boglishman was dropped with a deftly-fling | stone on the temple. Being real grit he picked himself up, closad with his man, and he'd him till a policeman came ap, nor did be inflict any further violence on the man afcer appre- hending him. He, however, had no evidence , while the very horses were, believe, prepared to give testimooy on tha o-her side, also the policeman, whom my frisad hai omittei to win over. the arbaghi for assanit and fired £5 and £3 ee the able-bodied cripple—with or without oso- motive applianees—and worse, far worse than all, — the starving, maimed, aad soffering children with parente—or other adalts in that guise — watehing them from some point of vantage.

There is now on the streets of Cairo a tall, fine-looking fellah about thirty years of age, who leads by the hand an emaciated, filthy little girl, a mere child of five or so. She has hor feet tarned iow srds and her legs are too weak to sapport her body for aey distance. "he man come; toa oafé or open bar, gives thechild a paxh andin she staggers, falls on har kanes, with her contorted limbs doubled ander her, and whines shrilly. When she comes out the man takes what she has ia cash, throws aay food away that she may have reosived, and drags her along to the next likely resort. If the couple meet a respeoctably dressed pedestrian moving slowly along some more or less deserted street the same process is gone throagh with the same resalt. 1 have given the aofortuoat: child money, and food, as many others do, bat I determioed to watch the procesdiags, with the above resalt. The man I have often seea withoat his stock-in- trade, the centre of « large and garralous throng at one of the lower-class cafés and, apparently, at once the host and eatertainer of the party. Faugh!! It isenoogh to make a bysena sick to think of it.

Is there no remedy ! Is this inoflax of meodicants in the tourist season too great for the police to cope with or is no eff rt made t» keep sach people within the boands of ordinary deescy aod hemanity! I regret the length of this article, aor om I[ per- haps the best person to write on sach sahjscts, bat if | can thereby prevent the maltraatmenot and explvitatioa of one wretched ohild, I shall feel that it has no: boea written in vain. Tad travelling apper-classes, who form the mainstay of Cairo’s wealth, and who pre- samably have sach delicacy and sympathy as a libaral edacatioa shoald give, are hardly likely to look with favoar oa a city where gach naaseoas, harrowiag, aad disgasting experiences are of daily oocsarrenca, and practically anavoidsble.—Yours feithfally, AppaLlan Manson.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: This morning's tel show that the gallantry of Prince Henry ot the Netherlands at the wreck of the Berlin has been warmly appreciated in Eagiand. The Prince married Q een Wilhelmina io 1901. He belongs to the Hoase of Mecklembarg-Schwerio and was born in 1876
we regret to learn that Princess Nazli Hinem Fadi hae soffered a relapse and her condition iospires some anxiéty.
Fathi Bev Zighloal, the new Under Secretary to the Muioistry of Jastice, visited that Ministry on Monday, accompanied by the Judicial Adviser.

Mr. Hobler, late of the British Agency, Cairo, is proceeding to Adis Abeba to take over the offi sial daties of Sir John Harring ton, Minister Plevipotentiaty and Consal General, during the latter's absénce from Abyssinia on lesve.
Hassein Pasha Moharrem, Obief A. D. C. to the Khedive, has not retired on pension, as repor'ei. It is his brother, Dr. Hagen Bey Moharrem, who has retired from his Highn ess's service
Mr. Wells, luspector of Miner, will leave Cairo shortly for Keneh and thence proceed to the Red Sea Coast, where he will inspect the mining concessions.

div.head: IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT
DR. MCEKNNA'S BILL
RECOGNITION OF PRINCE'S BRAVERY
div.p: London, February 26

House or Commons.—Dr. McKenva’s Bill was reai for the first time and adopted by 264 votes to 109. [t provides that denominations! sohool managers should refand to the locs| authorities one-fifteenth of the teachers’ salaries, representing the cost of denominationa instraction, otherwise the school would cease to be recognised. Mr. Balfour did not oppose the measure.

Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman announced that the King bad conferred the Grand Cross of the Bath on Peince Henry of the Netherlands for | bravery in connection with the Berlin disaster. | He added that the House woald rejoice to see | the speedy recognition of his conspicaons gallantry and devotion. Sir B. Grey has te- legraphed to the British Minister at the Hague Great Britain's warm appreciation of the work of rescue carried out by Prince Henry and the lifeboatmen, whose names he reqvested to be forwarded with a view to their being suitably rewarded
(Feuter)

div.head: THE GERMAN ELECTIONS
GOVERNMENT TACTICS CONDEMNED
div.p: Berlin, February 26

Prince von Bu'ow, replying to attacks of the Centre on the Government's election tactics, described as inventions the allegation of the interference of the Crown. The Government claimed the right to enlighten electors and would dbe this right on s moch larger ecale in fatare elections.
( Reuter )
Berlin, February 26

In the Reichstag, Herr Bebel stigmatiad the official candidatares. Prince von Bulow reproached the Socialists fof their anti-patriotic attitade and appesled to the anion of the midile classes to render the defeat of tle Socialists definitive.
(Havas)

div.head: GERMAN COLONIES
div.p: Berlin, February 26
Herr Dernburg will start on a four months tour in East Africa in May
(Fueter)

div.head: FRENCH SENATE
div.p: Paris, February 26
The Senate has passed the Bill relating to public meetings
(Havas)

div.head: EXPLOSION ON WARSHIP
div.p: Corps, February 26
A bolier explosion has occurred on H.M.S Dragon. Two men were killed and four injured.
(Feuter)

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

Sulphur Bath Establishment.- Sulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masseurs and Masseuses. Every modern improvement.
